[Jerusalem. First station.] Daunce Here entryth Saule, goodly besene in Ã¾e best wyse, lyke an aunterous knyth, thus sayyng: SAULUS. Most dowtyd man I am lyuyng vpon the ground, Goodly besene, wyth many a ryche garlement! My pere on lyue I trow ys nott found! Thorow Ã¾e world, fro Ã¾e oryent to Ã¾e occydent, My fame ys best knowyn vndyr Ã¾e fyrmament! I am most drad of pepull vnyuersallâ They dare not dysp[l]ease me most noble! Saule ys my nameâI wyll Ã¾at ye notyfyâ Whych conspyreth the dyscyplys wyth thretys and menacys; Before Ã¾e pryncys of prestys most noble and hye, I bryng them to punnyshement for ther trespace. We wyll them nott suffer to rest in no place, For they go abou?te to preche and gyff exemplis To destroye oure lawes, sinagoges, and templis. By the god Bellyall, I schall make progresse Vnto the pryncys, both Caypha and Anna, Where I schall aske of them in suernes To persue thorow all Dammask and Liba. And thus we schall soone after than Bryng them Ã¾at so do lyff into Jerusalem, Both man and child that I fynd of them! Her cummyth Sale to Caypha and Anna, prestys of Ã¾e tempyll. Nobyll prelatys and pryncys of regalyte, Desyryng and askyng, of your benyngne wurthynes, Your letters and epystolys of most souerente, To subdue rebellyous that wyll of frawardnes Agaynst our lawes rebell or transgresse, Nor wyll not inclyne, but mak obiecc[y]on; To pursue all such, I wyll do proteccyon. CAYPHA. To your desyer we gyf perfyth sentens, Accordyng to your petycyons that ye make postulacyon, Bycause we know your trewe delygens To persue all tho Ã¾at do reprobacyon Agayns owur lawes by ony redarguacyon. Wherefor, shortly we gyf in commandment To put down them Ã¾at be dy[s]obedyent. ANNA. And by thes letturs Ã¾at be most reuerrent, Take them in hand, full agre Ã¾erto, Constreyne all rebellys by owur hole assent, We gyf yow full power so to doo. Spare not hardly for frend nor foo! All thos ye fynd of Ã¾at lyfe in thys realme, Bounde, loke ye bryng them into Jerusalem! Her Saule resayuyth ther letters. SAULUS. Thys precept here I take in hande, To fullfyll after yowur wyllys both, Wher I shall spare wythin Ã¾is londe Nother man nor womanâto Ã¾is I make an othâ But to subdue, I wyll not be loth! Now folow me, knytys and seruauntys trewe, Into Damaske, as fast as ye can sewe! PRIMUS MILES. Vnto your commaundment I do obeysaunce. I wyll not gaynsay nor make delacyon, But wyth good mynd and harty plesaunce I shall yow succede, and make perambulacyon Thorowoute Damaske wyth all delectacyon, And all thoo rebell and make resystens, For to oppres I wyll do my delygens. SECUNDUS MILES. And in me shalbe no neclygens, But to thys precept myself I shall applye: To do your behest wyth all conuenyens, Wythowt eny frowardnes or eny obstynacyâ Non shall appere in meâ but, verely, Wyth all my mynd I yow insure, To resyst tho rebellys I wyll do my cure! SAULUS. Truly, to me yt ys grett consolacyon To here thys report Ã¾at ye do avauns. For your sapyencyall wyttys I gyf commendacyon! Euer at my nede I haue founde yow constant. But, knytys and seruuantys Ã¾at be so plesaunt, I pray yow anon my palfray ye bryng, To spede my jurney wythowt lettyng! Here goyth Sale forth a lytyll asyde for to make hym redy to ryde, the seruua[n]t thus seyng: SERUUS. How, hosteler, how! A peck of otys and a botell of haye! Com of apase, or I wyll to another inne! What, hosteler, why commyst not thy way? Hye Ã¾e faster! I beshrew Ã¾i skynne! STABULARYUS. I am non hosteler, nor non hostelers kynne, But a jentylmanys seruuant, I! Ãou dost know Such crabyysh wordys do aske a blow! SERUUS. I cry yow mercy, syr! I wyst well sumwhat ye were, OwÃ¾er a gentylman or a knaue, me thynkyth by your physnomy! Yf on loke yow in Ã¾e face Ã¾at neuer se yow ere, Wold thynk ye were at Ã¾e next dore by! In good fayth, I wenyd yow had bene an hosteler, verely. In fayth, Ã¾ou neuer syest me tyll Ã¾is day! I haue dwellyd wyth my master thys seuen ?ere and more. Full well I haue pleasyd hym, he wyll not say nay, And mykyll he makyth of me therfore! SERUUS. By my trowth, Ã¾an be ye changyd to a new lore? A seruand ye are, and Ã¾at a good! Ther ys no better lokyth owt of a hood! STABULARIUS. Forsoth, and a hood I vse for to were, Full well yt ys lynyd wyth sylk and chamlett; Yt kepyth me fro the cold, Ã¾at Ã¾e wynd doth me not dere, Nowther frost nor snow Ã¾at I therby do sett. SERUUS. Yea, yt ys a dobyll hood, and Ã¾at a fett. He was a good man Ã¾at made yt, I warant yowâ He was nother horse ne mare nor yet yokyd sow! Here commyth Ã¾e fyrst knyth knyth to Ã¾e stabylgrom, sayng: PRIMUS MILES. Now, stabyllgrom, shortly bryng forth away The best horse, for owur lorde wyll ryde! STABYLARIUS. I am full redy! Here ys a palfray, Ther can no man a better bestryde! He wyll conducte owur lorde and gyde Thorow the world; he ys sure and abyll To bere a gentyllman, he [ys] esy and prophetabyll. Her Ã¾e knyth cummyth to Saule wyth a horse. PRIMUS MILES. Behold, Syr Saule! Your palfray ys comm, Full goodly besene, as yt ys yowur desyer, To take yowur vyage thorow euery regyon. Be nott in dowt he wyll spede your mater, And we, as your seruauntys, wyth glad chere Shall gyf attendance. We wyll nott gaynsay, But folow yow where ye go, be ny?t or day! SAULUS. Vnto Damask I make my progressyon To pursue all rebellyous beyng froward and obstynate Agayns our lawes be ony transgressyon. Wyth all my delygens myself I wyll prepar[at]e, Concernyng my purpose to oppres and seperate; Non shall reioyce that doth offend, But vtterly to reproue wyth mynde and intende. Her Sale rydyth forth wyth hys seruantys abowt Ã¾e place, owt of Ã¾e plÂ«aceÂ». CAYPHA. Now Saule hath takyn hys wurthy wyage To pursue rebellyous, of what degre Ã¾ei be, He wyll non suffer to raygne nor haue passage Wythin all thys regyon, we be in sertayn[te]. Wherefor I commende hys goodly dygnyte, That he thus aluay takyth in hande, By hys power to gouerne thus all thys lande. ANNA. We may lyue in rest by hys consolacyon. He defendyth vs, wherefor we be bownde To loue hym intyrely wyth our harttys affeccyon, And honour hym as champyon in euery stownde. Ther ys non such lyuyng vpon Ã¾e grownde, That may be lyke to hym, nor be hys pere, Be est nor west, ferre nor nere! Poetaâsi placet. Daunce Conclusyon [POETA]. POETA. Honorable frendys, we beseche yow of audyens To here our intencyon, and also our prosses. Vpon our matter, be your fauorable lycens, Another part of Ã¾e story we wyll redres: Here shalbe brefly shewyd, wyth all our besynes, At thys pagent Saynt Poullys conuercyon. Take ye good hede, and therto gyf affeccyon! Here commyth Saule, rydyng in wyth hys seruantys. SAULUS. My purpose to Damask fully I intende; To pursewe the dyscypulys, my lyfe I apply! For to breke down the chyrchys thus I condescende. Non I wyll suffer that shall edyfeyâ Perchaunce owur lawes they my?te therby, And the pepull also, turne and conuerte, Whych shuld be gret heuynes vnto myn hart. Nay, Ã¾at shall nott be butt layd apart! Ãe prynces haue gouyn me full potestacyonâ All that I fynd, Ã¾ei shall nott start, But bounde to Jerusalem, wyth furyous vyolacyon, Befor Cesar, Caypha, and Annas [have] presentacyon. Thus shalbe subduyd tho wretchys of Ã¾at lyfe, That non shall injoy, nother man, chy[l]de, nor wyfe! Here comyth a feruent, wyth gret tempest, and Saule faulyth down of hys horse; Ã¾at done, Godhed spekyth in heuyn: DEUUS. Saule, Saule! Why dost Ã¾ou me pursue? Yt ys hard to pryke agayns Ã¾e spore! I am Ã¾i Savyour Ã¾at ys so trwe, Whych made heuyn and erth, and eche creature. Offende nott my goodnes; I wyll Ã¾e recure! SAULUS. O Lord, I am aferd, I trymble for fere! What woldyst I ded? Tell me here! DEUS. Aryse, and goo Ã¾ou wyth glad chere Into the cyte a lytyll besyde, And I shall Ã¾e socor in euery dere, That no maner of yll xal betyde, And I wyll ther for the prouyde By my grete goodnes what Ã¾ou shalt doo. Hy Ã¾e as fast thether as Ã¾ou mast goo. SAULUS. O mercyfull God, what aylyth me? I am lame, my leggys be take me fro! My sygth lykwyse, I may nott see! I can nott tell whether to goo! My men hath forsake me also. Whether shall I wynde, or whether shall I pas? Lord, I beseche the, helpe me of thy grace! PRIMUS MILES. Syr, we be here to help the in Ã¾i nedeâ Wyth all our affyance we wyll nott sesse! SAULUS. Than in Damask I pray yow me lede, I[n] Godys name, accordyng to my promyse. SECUNDUS MILES. To put forth yowur hand, loke ye dresse. Cum on your way! We shall yow bryng Into Ã¾e cyte wythowt taryng. Here the knyghtys lede forth Sale into a place, and Cryst apperyth to Annanie, sayng: DEUS. Ananie, Ananie! Where art Ã¾ou, Ananie? ANANIAS. Here, Lord! I am here trwly! DEUS. Go thy way, and make Ã¾i curse As I shall assyng Ã¾e by myn aduysse, Into Ã¾e strete, qui dicitur rectus, And in a certayn house, of warantyse, Ther shall ye fynd Saule in humble vyse, As a meke lambe Ã¾at a wolf before was namyd. Do my behest! Be nothyng ashamyd! He wantyth hys syth, by my punyshment constrayned; Prayeng vnto me, I assure Ã¾ou shalt hym fynd. Wyth my stroke of pyte sore ys he paynyde, Wantyng hys sygth, for he ys truly blynyde. ANANIAS. Lord, I am aferd, for aluay in my mynd I here so myche of hys furyous cruelte, Ãat for spekyng of Ã¾i name to deth he will put me. DEUS. Nay, Ananie, nay, I assure Ã¾e, He wulbe glad of thy cummyng! ANANIAS. A, Lord, but I know of a certayn[te] That thy seyntys in Jerusalem to deth he doth bryng! Many yllys of hym I haue bekennyng, For he hath the poure of the pryncys alle, To saue or spylle, do which he schall. DEUS. Be nothyng a-drad! He ys a chosen wessell, To me assyngned by my Godly eleccyon. He shall bere my name before the kyngys and chylder of Israell, By many sharpe shourys sufferyng correccyon; A gret doctor of benyngne conpleccyon, The trwe precher of the hye deuynete, A very pynacle of Ã¾e fayth, I ensure the. ANANYAS. Lorde, thy commandment I shall fullfyll; Vnto Saule I wyll take my waye. DEUS. Be nothyng in dowte for good nor yll. Farewell, Ananie! Tell Saule what I do say. Et exiat Deus. ANANIAS. Blyssyd Lord, defende me as Ã¾ou best may! Gretly I fere hys cruell tyranny, But to do Ã¾i precept, myself I shall applye. Here Ananias goth toward Saule. PRIMUS MYLES. I maruayle gretly what yt doth mene, To se owur master in thys hard stounde! The wonder grett lythtys Ã¾at were so shene Smett hym doune of hys hors to Ã¾e grownde, And me thowt that I hard a sounde Of won spekyng wyth voyce delectable, Whych was to [vs] wonderfull myrable. SECUNDUS MYLES. Sertenly thys ly?t was ferefull to see, The sperkys of fyer were very feruent! Yt inflamyd so greuosely about Ã¾e countre, That, by my trowth, I went we shuld a bene brent! But now, serys, lett vs relente Agayne to Caypha and Anna to tell Ã¾is chaunce, How yt befell to vs thys greuauns. Her Saule ys in comtemplacyon. SAULUS. Lord, of Ã¾i coumfort moch I desyre, Ãou my?ty Prynce of Israell, Kyng of pyte, Whyche me hast punyshyd as Ã¾i presoner, That nother ete nor dranke thys dayes thre. But, gracyos Lorde, of Ã¾i vysytacyon I thanke the; Thy seruant shall I be as long as I haue breth, Thowgh I therfor shuld suffer dethe. Here commyth Anania to Saule, sayeng: ANANIAS. Pease be in thys place and goodly mansyon! Who ys wythin? Speke, in Crystys holy name! SALUS. I am here, Saule! Cum in, on Goddys benyson! What ys your wyll? Tell, wythowten blame. ANANIAS. From Almyghty God sertanly to the sent I am, And Ananie men call me wheras I dwell. SAULUS. What wold ye haue? I pray yow me tell! ANANIAS. Gyfe me your hand for your awayle; For as I was commaundyd by hys gracyos sentens, He bad the be stedfast, for Ã¾ou shalt be hayle. For thys same cause he sent me to Ã¾i presens. Also, he bad the remember hys hye excellens, Be Ã¾e same tokyn Ã¾at he dyd Ã¾e mete Toward Ã¾e cyte, when he apperyd in Ã¾e strete. Ther mayst Ã¾ou know hys power celestyall, How he dysposyth euery thyng as hym lyst; Nothyng may wythstand hys my?te essencyall; To stond vpryght, or els doun to thrysteâ Thys ys hys powur, yt may not be myste, For who Ã¾at yt wantyth, lackyth a frende. Thys ys Ã¾e massage Ã¾at he doth Ã¾e sende. SAULUS. His marcy to me ys ryght welcom! I am ryght glad Ã¾at yt ys thus. Hic aparebit Spiritus Sanctus super eum. ANANIAS. Be of good chere and perfyte jubylacyon! Discendet super te Sprytus Sanctus, Whych hath wyth hys hye grace illumynyd vs. Put fo[r]th Ã¾i hond, and goo wyth meâ Agayne to thy syght here I restore the! SAULUS. Blyssyd Lord, thankys to yow euer bee! The swame ys fallyn from my eyes twayne! Where I was blynyd and cowd nott see, Lord, Ã¾ou hast sent me my syght agayne. From sobbyng and wepyng I can not refrayne My pensyue hart full of contryccyon; For my offencys, my body shal haue punycyon. And where I haue vsed so gret persecucyon Of Ã¾i descyplys thorow all Jerusalem, I wyll [ayd] and defende ther predycacyon, That th[e]y dyd tech on all Ã¾is reme. Wherefor, Ananie, at the watery streme Baptyse me, hartely I Ã¾e praye, Among your numbyr, that I electe and chosen be may! ANANIAS. Onto Ã¾is well of mych vertu We wyll vs hye wyth all our delygens! SAULUS. Go yow before, and after I shall sewe, Laudyng and praysyng our Lordys benevolens! I shall neuer offend hys my?ty magnyfycens, But aluay obserue hys preceptys, and kepe. For my gret vnkyndnes my hart doth wepe! ANANIAS. Knele ye down vpon thys grownde, Receyuyng thys crystenyng wyth good intent, Whyche shall make yow hole of your dedly wound That was infecte wyth venom nocent. Yt purgyth synne, and fendys pourys so fraudelent It putyth asyde; where thys doth attayne, In euery stede, he may not obtayne! I crysten yow, wyth mynd full perfyght, Reseyuyng yow into owur relygyon, Euer to be stedfast, and neuer to flyt, But euer constant, wythowt varyacyon. Now ys fulfyllyd all our obseruacyon, Concludyng, Ã¾ou mayst yt ken, In nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti, Amen. SAULUS. I am ryght glad as foule on flyte That I haue receyuyd Ã¾is blyssyd sacrement! ANANIAS. Com on your way, Saule, for nothyng lett! Take yow sum coumforth for your bodyes noryschment. Ye shall abyde wyth Ã¾e dyscyplys verament Thys many dayes in Damask cyte, Vntyll Ã¾e tyme more perfyt ye may be. SAULUS. As ye commande, holy father Ananie, I full assent at yow[ur] request, To be gydyd and rulyd as ye wyll haue me, Evyn at your pleasur, as ye thynk best; I shall not offend, for most nor lest. Go forth yowur way, I wyll succede Into what place ye wyll me lede. Daunce Conclusyo POETA. Thus Saule ys conuertyd, as ye se expres, The very trw seruant of our Lord Jhesu. Non may be lyke to hys perfy?t holynes, So nobyll a doctor, constant and trwe; Aftyr hys conuersyon neuer mutable, but styll insue The lawys of God to teche euer more and more, As Holy Scrypture tellyth whoso lyst to loke Ã¾erfore. Thus we comyte yow all to Ã¾e Trynyte, Conkludyng thys stacyon as we can or may, Vnder Ã¾e correccyon of them Ã¾at letteryd be; Howbeyt vnable, as I dare speke or say, The compyler hereof shuld translat veray So holy a story, but wyth fauorable correccyon Of my honorable masters, of Ã¾er benygne supplexion. Finis istius secunde stacionis et sequitur tarcia.

POETA. The myght of the Fadirys potenciall Deite Preserue thys honorable and wurshypfull congregacyon, That here be present of hye and low degre, To vnderstond thys pagent at thys lytyll stacyon, Whych we shall procede wyth all our delectac[y]on, Yf yt wyll plese yow to gyf audyens fauorable. Hark wysely thertoâyt ys good and profetable! [Jerusalem. Caypha and Anna in the temple. Enter the knights.] PRIMUS MILES. Nobyll prelatys, take hede to owur sentens! A wundyrfull chaunce fyll and dyd betyde Vnto owur master Saull when he departyd hens, Into Damaske purposyd to ryde. A meruelous ly?t fro th'element dyd glyde, Whyche smet doun hym to grunde, both horse and man, Wyth the ferfulest wether Ã¾at euer I in cam! SECUNDUS MILES. It rauysshid hym, and his spiritys did benomme! A swete dulcet voyce spake hym vnto, And askyd wherfor he made suche persecucyon Ageynst hys dyscyplys, and why he dyd soo. He bad hym into Damaske to Ananie goo, And ther he shuld reseyue baptym truly; And now clene ageyns owur lawys he ys, trwly! CAYPHA. I am sure thys tale ys not trw! What, Saule conuertyd from our law? He went to Damask for to pursue All the dyscyplys that dyd wythdraw Fro owur faythâthys was hys sawe! How say ye, Anna, to thys mater? Ãis ys a mervelos chans! I can not beleve Ã¾at thys ys of assurans! ANNA. No, Caypha, my mynde trwly do [I] tell, That he wyll not turne in no maner wyse, But rather to deth put and expell All myscreauntys and wretchys Ã¾at doth aryse Agaynst our lawes be ony enterpryse! Say the trwth, wyth[owt] ony cause frawdelent, Or els, for your talys, ye be lyke to be shent! PRIMUS MILES. Ellys owur bodyes may [ye] put to payn! All Ã¾at we declare, I sye yt wyth my nyeâ Nothyng offendyng, but trwly do iustyfye! CAYPHAS. By the gret god, I do maruayle gretly! And thys be trw Ã¾at ye do reherse, He shall repent hys rebellyous treytory, That all shalbe ware of hys falsnes! We wyll not suffer hym to obtayne, dowtles, For meny perellys Ã¾at myght betyde, By hys subtyll meanys on euery syde. ANNA. The law ys commyttyd to owur aduysment, Wherfor we wyll not se yt decay, But rather vphold yt, help and agment, That ony reprofe to vs fall may Of Cesar th'emproure by ny?t or day! We shall to such maters harke and attende, Accordyng to the lawes, our wyttys to spende! DIABOLUS (The following passage cancelled in manuscript) Her apperyth Saule in a disciplis wede, sayeng: SAULUS. That Lord Ã¾at ys shaper of see and of sond, And hath wrowth wyth hys woord all thyng at hys wyll, Saue thys semely Ã¾at here syttyth or stonde, For hys meke marcy Ã¾at we do nott spyll. Grant me, good Lord, thy pleasure to fulfyll, And send me suche speche that I Ã¾e trwth say, My entencyons proph[e]table to meve yf I may. Welbelouyd frendys, ther be seuen mortall synnes, Whych be provyd pryncypall and pryncys of poysonnes. Pryde, Ã¾at of bytternes all bale begynnes, Wythholdyng all fayth, yt fedyth and foysonnes, As Holy Scryptur beryth playn wyttnesse: âInicium omnium peccatorum superbya estââ That often dystroyeth both most and lest! (End of cancelled passage) Here to enter a dyvel wyth thunder and fyre, and to avaunce hymsylfe, sayeng as folowyth, and hys spech spokyn, to syt downe in a chayre: BELYALL. Ho, ho, beholde me, Ã¾e my?te prynce of Ã¾e partys infernall! Next vnto Lucyfer I am in magestye! By name I am nominate Ã¾e god Belyallâ Non of more my?te nor of more excellencye! My powre ys pryncypall, and now of most soferaynte; In Ã¾e templys and synagogys who deneyth me to honore, My busshopys, thorow my motyon, Ã¾ei wyl hym sone devoure! I haue movyd my prelatys, Cayphas and Anna, To persew and put downe by powre ryall, Thorow Ã¾e sytyes of Damaske and Liba, All soch as do worship Ã¾e hye God supernall. There deth ys conspyryd wythowt any fauoure at all; My busshopys hathe chosyne won most rygorus Them to persew, howse name ys Saulus. Ho!
